channel.title: Onion Grater resists Unicode spoofing?
channel.description:
I'm not sure if this has any implications for Tor even if it was feasible but its good to know if the exact characters are validated and nothing is accepted that looks like them. For example Cyrillic that resembles Latin "O".
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/IDN_homograph_attack

item.title: Onion Grater resists Unicode spoofing?
item.dc:creator: HulaHoop
item.description:
I’m not sure if this has any implications for Tor even if it was feasible but its good to know if the exact characters are validated and nothing is accepted that looks like them. For example Cyrillic that resembles Latin “O”.

en.m.wikipedia.org

IDN homograph attack

The internationalized domain name (IDN) homograph attack is a way a malicious party may deceive computer users about what remote system they are communicating with, by exploiting the fact that many different characters look alike (i.e., they are homographs, hence the term for the attack, although technically homoglyph is the more accurate term for different characters that look alike). For example, a regular user of example.com may be lured to click a link where the Latin character "a" is replace...

Read full topic
